Key Arguments: The Bill is an attack on free speech and represents government overreach.
It is inconsistent with international human rights obligations and European laws.
The Bill allows government and big tech to censor speech beyond reasonable limits.
Government communications are exempt, creating an asymmetry in speech regulation.
The Bill's definition of 'harm' is vague and could be misused to suppress legitimate speech.
Penalties for non-compliance are excessive and could chill free speech.
There is insufficient accountability and oversight for misuse of censorship powers.
The Bill grants ACMA excessive powers, breaching privacy.
Notable Quotes: This Bill will impose some of the most draconian controls on free speech in the Western world.
The Bill puts too much power in the hands of unelected bureaucrats to silence speech in the public square without transparency or accountability.
